ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: knowledge of post classical Islamic theology and philosophy

-Critical thinking -In-depth study of Fakhr ad-din ar-Razi -Issues and variations of these issues in medieval Islamic thought -Thoughtful translations - Dealing with research questions that have been little studied -Thinking about particular scholars within a greater context of intellectual history before and after the scholar's time.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It was a really good course
The course was extremely helpful. I appreciate the detail and nuance given to each subject tackled in the course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It depends what they are interested in. If they have an interest in Islamic theology absolutely. The figure studied is highly important in Islamic intellectual history. The class is organized so that all the work a student puts in will be drawn out in class, which is satisfying and evidence of good pedagogy.
